discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
root user privileges, in order to connect via ssh on the host and run esxtop

Selected Answer: A
You can run the esxtop utility using the ESXi Shell to communicate with the management interface of the ESXi host. You must have root user privileges.

questions.question_text: Which privilege is required to run the esxtop utility?

An administrator is asked to take a snapshot of a virtual machine prior to an application upgrade. The virtual machine has one standard virtual machine disk
(VMDK) and one physical mode raw device mapping (RDM) attached.
Which statement is true with regard to taking this snapshot?

choices.B: The administrator will be able to snapshot the standard VMDK in independent persistent mode.
choices.D: The administrator will be able to snapshot both disks.
choices.A: The administrator will be unable to snapshot the RDM.
choices.C: The administrator will be able to snapshot the RDM in independent persistent mode.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
IT happend to me in a project

RDM will not be taken in a snapshot as it is physical, however if it was virtual it will be available for snapshot
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-0114693D-94BF-4D0E-9BA4-416D4A51A5A1.html

Selected Answer: A
VMware does not support snapshots of raw disks, RDM physical mode disks, or guest operating systems that use an iSCSI initiator in the guest.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.hostclient.doc/GUID-53F65726-A23B-4CF0-A7D5-48E584B88613.html

Selected Answer: A
A. The administrator will be unable to snapshot the RDM. 

VMware does not support snapshots of raw disks, RDM physical mode disks, or guest operating systems that use an iSCSI initiator in the guest. 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-53F65726-A23B-4CF0-A7D5-48E584B88613.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIC5gNYFMAEZUGcB2YAOmAFgPZyoBKAIgLIgC+QA

Selected Answer: C
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.monitoring.doc/GUID-A31249BF-B5DC-455B-AFC7-7D0BBD6E37B6.html

questions.question_text: Which local only host utility is used for primary, real-time performance monitoring in vSphere?

choices.C: An ESXi 7.0 host can automatically upgrade a VMFS5 datastore.
choices.E: A VMFS3 datastore cannot be upgraded; a new VMFS6 datastore is required.
choices.D: An ESXi 7.0 host will automatically upgrade a VMFS3 datastore when discovered.
choices.A: VMFS5 is no longer supported with ESXi 7.0.
choices.B: VMFS3 is no longer supported with ESXi 7.0.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is tasked with upgrading an existing VMware vSphere 6.5 environment to version 7.0.
There are existing VMFS3 and VMFS5 datastores in the environment.
Which two statements are true regarding this upgrade? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
you are absolutely right :
VMFS3 Datastores
ESXi no longer supports VMFS3 datastores. The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores. The host performs the upgrade operation in the following circumstances:
At the first boot after an upgrade to ESXi 7.0 or later, when the host mounts all discovered VMFS3 datastores.
When you manually mount the VMFS3 datastores that are discovered after the boot, or mount persistently unmounted datastores.
Then, the right answer is BD

My Bad. Correct for is BC
VMFS3 Datastores
ESXi no longer supports VMFS3 datastores. The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores

VMFS3 is NOT automatically upgrade.

For me BE

discussion.content:
B and D are Correct 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-DAD74662-E09E-44A4-82F1-DB7A3433CEF9.html

B and D
A is false
C is also false as you cannot upgrade VMFS 5 to VMFS 6
E is also false as you can very much upgrade VMFS 3 to VMFS 5
That leaves B and D (B is also a bit wrong, just less wrong than the others as in you can use VMFS 3 but cannot create VMFS 3 in ESXi 7)

Selected Answer: BD
You can upgrade a VMFS3 datastore but not a VMFS 5 datastore. VMFS3 is no longer supported in vSphere 7, but VMFS5 is. Therefore B and D are correct

ESXi no longer supports VMFS3 datastores. The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores. - This statement confuses a lot! it might be VMFS6 instead.. because what's the use of upgrading to VMFS5? when they say that If you have a VMFS5 datastore in your environment, create a VMFS6 datastore and migrate virtual machines from the VMFS5 datastore to VMFS6.

Selected Answer: BD
B and D are correct.
ESXi no longer supports VMFS3 datastores. The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-DAD74662-E09E-44A4-82F1-DB7A3433CEF9.html

Selected Answer: BD
The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores. However that is due to ESXi no longer supporting VMFS3 which is where this confusion is tied.

You cannot upgrade a VMFS5 datastore to VMFS6, this must be migrated from one datastore to another IE the example provided VMFS5 to VMFS6.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-DAD74662-E09E-44A4-82F1-DB7A3433CEF9.html

comments.content:
A, C are definitely both false, it is either B,D or B,E.
B is definitely true. 
Then D or E, whichever way you look at it. 
D, VMFS3 is automatically upgraded but only to VMFS5
E, VMFS3 cannot be upgraded to VMFS6, a new VMFS6 has to be created.

I would Choose E because it aligns with the goal of the upgrade to vsphere7, why would you want to upgrade to vsphere 7 and keep your storage at VMFS5

WRONG! is supported RW

GOOD. Will be upgraded on mount
C. An ESXi 7.0 host can automatically upgrade a VMFS5 datastore.
WRONG

GOOD

WRONG
VMFS3 is Automatically upgraded to VMFS5 on the first mount.

comments.content: You are right about D being correct, but you gave the wrong reason. Yes VMFS3 will be automatically upgraded but not to VMFS6. Instead it will be upgraded to VMFS5, which is supported by 7.0, however VMs running on it will not benefit from new feature of VMFS6. The only way is to migrate VMs from the old VMFS5 to a new VMFS6 DS, Then use the old VMFS5 DS to create a new VMFS6 DS

discussion.content:
Correct answers are: B & D

A. False - VMFS5 is read/write
B. True - VMFS3 is no longer supported but datastores are automatically updated to VMFS6
C. False - VMFS5 cannot be upgraded to VMFS6. You need to create a new VMFS6 datastore and migrate the VMs
D. True - VMFS3 is automatically upgraded to VMFS6 when the datastore is mounted
E. False - See D

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-7552DAD4-1809-4687-B46E-ED9BB42CE277.html

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-DAD74662-E09E-44A4-82F1-DB7A3433CEF9.html
B and D is only correct statement.

A. VMFS5 is no longer supported with ESXi 7.0
Wrong!
B. VMFS3 is no longer supported with ESXi 7.0.
Wrong! ESXi no longer supports NEW VMFS3 datastores. The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores
C. An ESXi 7.0 host can automatically upgrade a VMFS5 datastore.
Wrong! You have to create a ne VMFS6 Datastore an migrate the VMs manualy
D. An ESXi 7.0 host will automatically upgrade a VMFS3 datastore when discovered.
Right! The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores
E. A VMFS3 datastore cannot be upgraded; a new VMFS6 datastore is required.
Right! See answer to c.

comments.content:
B is true, no supported, will upgrade, so D is true too.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-DAD74662-E09E-44A4-82F1-DB7A3433CEF9.html
E: false!!!
D is correct, but i struggle between b and e. Both looks right from a special point of view.

discussion.content: B and D correct
B and D are correct.

ESXi no longer supports VMFS3 datastores. The ESXi host automatically upgrades VMFS3 to VMFS5 when mounting existing datastores. The host performs the upgrade operation in the following circumstances:

 At the first boot after an upgrade to ESXi 7.0 or later, when the host mounts all discovered VMFS3 datastores.
 When you manually mount the VMFS3 datastores that are discovered after the boot, or mount persistently unmounted datastores.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-DAD74662-E09E-44A4-82F1-DB7A3433CEF9.html

I would choose B,D . ALL the rest is totally wrong.
however B is not totally correct but when u say vmfs3 is not supported and also choose will be upgraded automatically that might be ok ... true but just different wording.

questions.question_text: What is a requirement of Storage I/O Control?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
SIOC must be managed by a single vCenter Server system
SIOC supports FC, iSCSI, NFS but not RDM
SIOC does not support datastores with multiple extents

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.resmgmt.doc/GUID-37CC0E44-7BC7-479C-81DC-FFFC21C1C4E3.html

Selected Answer: B
Shared DS by many VC is not supported to have SIOC enabled

choices.B: Management by a single vCenter Server
